author: Jeff Whalley
title: CBA dismisses speculation of further cash calls
text:
THE Commonwealth Bank has dismissed speculation it will eventually need to turn to investors for another funding injection after tapping them for $5 billion in fresh capital.
Speaking as the group threw open its rights issue to household investors yesterday, CBA treasurer Paolo Tonucci said the bank was confident it was raising enough cash.
The group, Australia’s biggest bank, believed the $5 billion would be enough to cover any capital requirements ushered in the “foreseeable future,” Mr Tonucci told Business Daily .
Shares in the CBA fell more than 2 per cent in early trading yesterday — the first trading day since the bank unveiled the widely-expected capital raising program last Wednesday.
They recovered some ground later in the day, closing 1 per cent lower at $81.27
It came after the bank completed the institutional part of its rights issue, raising $2.1 billion.
The bank is now asking retail shareholders to pour in the remaining $2.9 billion for the $5 billion program through a renounceable entitlement offer.
About 90 per cent of eligible institutional investors took up their entitlements.
The bank’s 800,000 “mum and dad” shareholders are entitled to buy one new share for each 23 they own at $71.50 each, or trade their allocation.
That is a 10.5 per cent discount to the closing price last Tuesday, before the cash call was announced, adjusted for the bank’s final dividend.
CBA chief Ian Narev. Picture: AFP
The bank’s eligible retail shareholders — those who owned shares before the rights issue was announced last week — have until the close of business on September 8 to elect to buy shares in the program. But if they choose to sell their entitlements, they must do so on the stockmarket by September 1, or accept the proceeds allocated in a bookbuild on September 14.
CBA head of capital management Tricia Ho-Hudson said it was preferable for shareholders to “make an active decision­”. “They can watch over the two-week period and decide the price they want to sell (their entitlements) at. (If not) it will sell in bookbuild and you have only one price,” she said.
The bank announced the cash call last Wednesday as it unveiled a record $9.1 billion full-year net profit.
Mr Tonucci acknowledged there had been widespread speculation among analysts that the $5 billion capital raising program was too small and the bank would be forced to shake the can again in the coming year.
The banking watchdog, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, is pushing the banks to set aside more cash and account for more risk in their mortgage lending.
The international Basel Committee on Banking Supervision is also expected to soon announce its recommendations for how banks can insulate themselves against potential future financial shocks.
“I think there has been a lot of speculation by analysts about filling capital requirements ... (and that) these is still more capital needed,” Mr Tonucci said.
“Our view is we sized this to cover the implementation of the new mortgage rules — that really represents the bulk of capital change.”
The CBA’s program is the second biggest in Australian history after NAB earlier this year tapped investors for $5.5 billion.
